He looks away; your remark stung.

"Sorry," he says. "She’s just getting on my nerves. I know she’s had it rough. She and Ben were a thing, so she’s on edge even more than usual, I guess."

The two of you enter the cafeteria and then, after taking a precautionary look around, you go into the kitchen and stuff everything you can get your hands on into the two bags you brought from sickbay: fruit chips, soda, water bottles, pastries, canned soup.

When you’ve filled the bags, you leave the cafeteria and make your way to the common room. Strauss, Neil, and Salvucci are waiting. The common room is a circular room with a couch, several chairs, and a large wall-mounted monitor connected a server archive of countless movies, shows, and documentaries.  

On the back wall, there are portholes—just like on the ships of old that sailed the waters—where you can gaze into the dark of space.

"Run into any trouble?" Salvucci asks as you hand him the bag.

"Didn’t see a damn thing," Meat says.

"I’m telling you," Strauss says, rubbing her bandaged arm, "we won’t see it until it wants us to see it."

Meat grumbles something about paranoia and then heads over to the table, where Neil is setting up a checkers board.

"How’s your arm, doctor?" Salvucci asks.

"Fine, captain. Thank you."

You feel tired.

What should you do?

Meat fires the rifle across the room, the gun’s light chasing Markie’s feet as she darts away. You make a run for where you think the door is. Behind you, Neil screams in terror.
You hear the tell-tell click of the rifle as the clip goes dry. Meat swings the rifle around to point the flashlight at the door.

"Go!"

You find the handle and yank on it. Light bleeds into the darkness as you all sprint into the hallway. You slam the door and then bend over to catch your breath. Luckily, you manage to pull back just in time to avoid the spew of vomit that erupts from Neil’s mouth.

"That was Markie—our Markie?" he says, wiping the spittle from his lip.

"Yeah, it was," Meat answers, a tinge of sadness in his voice. He reloads the clip. "This is my last one."

"Why didn’t she attack us?"

1.[["She wants us to run out of ammo."]]
2.[["She's jerking us around."]]

He nods. "Yeah. I mean, it’s probably running around the ship, growing stronger by the minute, y’know?"

No one answers him. 

He takes a breath. "Okay, well, how are we going to do this?"

"We’ll go to the cafeteria—big, open space," says Meat.

You all make your way to the cafeteria, eyes watching the walls and vents. The journey is a safe one. 

All of you step into the mess hall.

Neil looks out across the tables like a man looking at his own grave.

"I always thought lunchrooms were kind of scary when I was a kids, ‘cause of the bullies and all. Never thought I’d die in one, though."

"You’ll be fine," Meat says. "We’ll be in the other room. You’re gonna stay in here and use your walkie."

"To do what?"

"Beg for help," Strauss says. "Cry. Be bait."

"How’s it gonna hear that?"

"Marki—what used to be Markie has a walkie clipped to her belt," Meat says.

"And if she thinks it’s a trap?"

"Then we come up with another plan. It’s animalistic though. I doubt it’ll pass up a wounded animal," Strauss answers.

"Gee thanks."

You, Meat, and Strauss step into the kitchen and move away from the door. He turns to you. "Make sure you have your gun ready, okay? I don’t want Neil to get eaten because we ran dry."

You check your pistol to make sure it has a full clip and nod. You all sit silently and listen to Neil in the other room. "Please help me," you hear him beg. "I can’t find you guys."

This goes on for 20 whole minutes, Neil’s acting growing steadily worse. "I fucking hurt my leg," he whimpers.

"A thespian, he is not," Strauss says.

"Just let the boy work," Meat replies, though it’s clear he’s getting tired of this as well.

"Oh fuck," Neil says.

"Well, we’re about to put an end to that shit," Meat says as you approach the crew’s quarters. You see large cables running through the doorway; they lead up the wall and into the ceiling.

Neil reaches up and runs his hand along the cables. He quickly pulls it back. "Augh! Fuck!"

"What is it?" Meat barks.

"Nothing," Neil says, regaining his composure. "Just fucking slime. Oh god, gag a maggot," he says. "This shit reeks." He holds his hand up to the light to reveal a goopy, transparent liquid.

"Hey, that looks a little bit like—"

"Don’t you fucking say it, Travis."

You examine the cables without touching them.

Meat takes a look as well. "Seems like a complicated operation."

"What, turning on the computer, starting a program, and plugging in some cables?"

Meat turns. "You didn’t see how feral this thing was—not to mention she’s missing a goddamn arm."

1.[["It might be Ben."]]

"Believe me, Zoe, I’m all for a long, relaxed, and rational conversation, but we can’t afford that luxury. She could expire and change at any moment."

"This is a bad horror movie," Ben moans, staring into the glass while Markie gazes at her own cauterized stump. She’s drooling now and has a nosebleed. You can see black veins popping beneath the skin on her forehead. It is like a bad horror movie.

"Enough," Salvucci says at last. "We’re not killing anyone on my ship—we’re not savages."

Meat is relieved. "Thanks boss."

"This is a mistake," Strauss says.

"Maybe," he says, "but it’s my mistake to make, not yours. Do what you can to keep her alive and prep her for cryo sleep."

"Again, a mistake."

"Doctor Strauss, unless you want to be brought before a military tribunal for insubordination, I suggest you do as I say.

"Yes, captain," she says, voice calm, but there’s a fire in her eyes. "Ben, lower the temperature to 15 degrees Fahrenheit. We’ll try to freeze her."

Markie looks up at you all. A smile breaks out over her face and then she leans over and pukes.

"Disgusting creature," Strauss mutters.

"Travis, Zoe, to the cockpit," Salvucci says.

"Do it, do it now."

You take aim at the switch on the far wall. You fire.
The shot slams into the switch, and the alarms blare. Meat slowly pulls himself along the rail until he’s behind the droids.

The hanger door opens and air swooshes out. You grip the railing beside you.

"Hold on!"

The beast begins to backslide toward the hanger door, its feet dragging. It tries to throw a tentacle at Meat, but they’re pulled as well. A moment later they snap off and go flying into the black.  Meat, clinging to the railing, kicks the droids. It takes a second for them to detach from their holders and tumble down into the behemoth. The first one knocks it back a couple of feet. The second droid seals the monster’s fate, knocking it off both of its feet and sending it careening into the stars.

"Eat shit and die, you fuck!" Meat screams through the comm. You can’t help but grin as the monster spins out of sight.

The alarms in the hanger continue to yell for a couple of seconds, and then the emergency seal protocol activates, and the hanger door slowly slides to a close again.

"We did it," Meat says. "We fucking did it."

He walks over to you and hugs you tightly. You both laugh.

"We’re alive!"

1.[["Let's get the fuck home, eh?"]]

Somehow you all manage to tell the cabbie your respective addresses. You stumble out of the cab at your house and tell the others you'll call them later.

Your house, it turns out, looks the same as it did before you left on your mission. You take two steps into the living room and fall onto the couch. You grip the cushions with your fingers and, face pressed into them, laugh.

You are home. You are alive and you are home. You wake up the next morning, mouth dry and head pounding. You take a shower and then call that doctor.

"Jessica," she tells you. "That's my name."

You ask her out for coffee. You meet her at a coffee shop and both you order terrible tasting drinks. It's clear you both like each other. She invites you back to her place, a nice apartment with windows that face the belly of the Valles Marineris. You make love; it's nice.

Soon you're dating. You agree to an open relationship but, within a month, you're dating exclusively.

The outpost in New Ausin has given you an analyst position. While you resent the military's decision that your disability keeps you from being combat ready, part of you is relieved to be away from danger (the raise is nice, too).

Your life is quiet, peaceful. You still meet up with Salvucci, Neil, and Meat from time to time at the bar. They like Jessica, though Neil is a bit too flirty with you for Jessica's liking.

Meat's there when you wake up. You're lying under a sheet on the examination table in sickbay and can't move."

Across the way you see Meat running. Ryan is nowhere to be found. You’ve covered half the distance to Meat when, looking up, you see the Speedwell beginning its descent.

You're almost to him when you hear Markie scream. Turning, you watch her fling one of the crab creatures across the ground.

"Fuck!" she yells.

Meat blasts the creature into pieces. The two of you rush over to her. She's holding her arm.

"It got me," she says; there's fear in her voice. She turns to Meat. "Where's Ryan?"

"Goddamn fucking thing ate him. It ATE him."

Meat's answer fills you with dread. No one that close to you has ever died before. Your vision becomes unfocused. A slap on the arm brings you back.

"We've got company, Zoe. I need you here and now," Meat says, nodding at the mouth of the cave where the crab creatures are gathering. There must be thousands of them. Luckily, behind you, you hear the Speedwell land.

Meat fires several shots at the crabs, but they don't seem to be leaving the cave anyway.

You and Meat help Markie to the ship’s elevator. Meat enters a combination on the keypad and the door slides open. Inside the elevator, as you ride up, all three of you remove your helmets. You notice for the first time that your face is drenched in sweat.

A ding. The door opens. Captain Jonas Salvucci, an older, muscular man with little patience of tomfoolery, awaits you, his hand wrapped around the pistol in his holster. He takes his hand away from the gun when he sees there’s no threat.

"Get her to sickbay."

You nod and help Markie through the hallway of the ship. Behind you, you can hear Salvucci interrogating Meat.

"What happened to Ryan?"

"Hell, Travis. What did you find down there?"

When you get to sickbay, both Lenore Strauss, the doctor, and her geeky assistant Ben are prepping the examination table.

"Where’s she wounded?" Lenore asks, as you help a woozy Markie out of her suit.  You glare at Ben as he gawks at her well-toned body. He smiles sheepishly and looks away, cheeks burning red with shame. Markie’s drenched in sweat; she stares around wildly as Lenore straps her in. She examines the bite: it’s just above the elbow, an inflamed bulging of the skin.

"And I was young and we were running," Markie rambles, "eyes bouncing up and down the shore  while the sun cooked the corpses of washed up jellyfish."

You turn to Lenore, who’s prepping some kind of tool.

You get in your pod and lay down. "Sweet dreams everyone," you hear Meat say right before your chamber shuts itself. 

Soon it's dark. You close your eyes. The world gets even darker.

When you awaken, you find yourself being assisted by a corporal. He takes you by the arm and guides you up from the pod.

From there, you, the captain, Meat, and Strauss are transported to the military outpost in New Austin. You are all given private rooms and access to nearly anything you could want. You order a steak on the first night and it's delicious.

Men in suits come and interview you about your experiences on the Speedwell. You answer their questions in as much detail as you can. They thank you for your time and promise you will be released soon.

"Soon" turns out to be three days later. You, Meat, Salvucci, and Strauss meet on the base and request a transport to the nearest bar. There, you all drink in merriment, celebrating your survival, though you allow yourselves to mournfully drink a round and say small eulogies for the dead: Ben, Markie, Neil, Ryan.

When you're all finished, you share a cab that drops you off at your respective addresses. You're the first. Your comrades tell you to call them soon just to check in. Inside your small house in the suburbs, you finally allow yourself a good cry. Not for the dead. Not for any reason at all, in particular, except that it's been inside you for so long, struggling to get out.

A week passes. You're relocated to an analyst position on the military base. You hear that Strauss is working at a research facility in New Memphis. You never talk to her, really, but Salvucci and Meat send you emails all the time. Both of them have been reassigned to on-base positions; Meat's an instructor, and Salvucci can't tell you what he does. You imagine it has something to do with what you found on earth.

Years pass. You never marry or have children, but you're never alone. Boys come and go, at a rate of about one every five years. You become attached to them all and break down in sobs when each one leaves. You never tell any of your lovers about your experience aboard the Speedwell.

You and Meat become close. You meet twice a week for lunch. On Wednesdays, you watch sitcoms; on Fridays, there's salsa night downtown. You get a dog. This is your existence and it proceeds one day after another.

You grow old; it's inevitable. Salvucci dies first. You and Meat attend his funeral. You both take bets on who's next; turns out it's you.

You pass away one night in your sleep, your dog curled up behind you with his snout against your back, the hound peacefully unaware of your endless slumber.
